[[Image:US homes over recommended radon levels.gif|thumb|upright=1.65|Predicted fraction of U.S. homes have radon concentrations exceeding the EPA's recommended action level of 4 pCi/L]] [[Radium]] and [[radon]] are important contributors to [[environmental radioactivity]]. Radon occurs naturally in the environment as a result of decay of [[radioactive]] elements in the soil and it can accumulate in houses built on areas where such decay occurs. This radon is among major causes of cancer, estimated to contribute to about 2% of all cancer related deaths in Europe.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Radon in homes and risk of lung cancer: collaborative analysis of individual data from 13 European case-control studies|last = Darby|date = January 29, 2005|journal = British Medical Journal|volume = 330|issue = 7485|page = 223|doi = 10.1136/bmj.38308.477650.63|pmid = 15613366|pmc=546066|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Radium, like radon, is a radioactive element and it is found in small quantities in nature and may thus be hazardous to life if concentrated. Radium has its origins as a decay product of certain isotopes of uranium and [[thorium]].<ref>Kirby et al. p. 3</ref> Radium may also be released to the environment as a result of human activity, for example, in inproperly discarded products painted with radioluminescent paint.
== Radium ==
===In the oil and gas industries ===
Residues from the [[Petroleum|oil]] and [[natural gas|gas]] industry often contain [[radium]] and its daughters. The sulfate scale from an oil well can be very radium rich. It is the case that the water inside an oil field is often very rich in [[strontium]], [[barium]] and [[radium]] while seawater is very rich in [[sulfate]] so if water from an oil well is discharged into the sea or mixed with seawater the radium is likely to be brought out of solution by the barium/strontium sulfate which acts as a [[Catalyst|carrier]] precipitate.<ref name="profile">{{Cite book|title = Toxicological Profile for Radon|last = Keith|first =S|publisher = Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (US)|date=May 2012|isbn = |location = Atlanta (GA) |display-authors=etal}}</ref>
=== Radioluminescent products, ie glow in the dark ===
Local contamination from radium-based [[Radioluminescence|radioluminescent]] paints having been improperly disposed of is not unknown.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=U.S. Radium Corp. |location=New Jersey |id=EPA ID#: NJD980654172 |title=EPA REGION 2, Congressional District(s): 10, Essex, City of Orange |date=February 5, 2010 |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120714234109/http://www.epa.gov/region02/superfund/npl/0200772c.pdf }}</ref>
=== In radioactive quackery ===
[[Eben Byers]] was a wealthy American socialite whose death in 1932 as a result of using an [[radioactive quackery]] product called [[Radithor]] is a prominent example of a death caused by radium. Radithor contained approximately 1 μCi (40 MBq) of <sup>226</sup>Ra and 1 μCi of <sup>228</sup>Ra per bottle. Radithor was taken by mouth and radium, being a [[calcium]] mimic, has a very long [[biological halflife]] in [[bone]].<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/82/21/1667.extract#|title = Radiation Therapy Pursuit Leads to Unearthing of "Hot Bones"|last = Vanchieri|first = Cori|date = November 7, 1990|journal = Journal of the National Cancer Institute|doi = 10.1093/jnci/82.21.1667|pmid = |access-date = January 31, 2015|volume=82|issue=21|page=1667}}</ref>
== Radon ==
[[File:Radon decay in a cloud chamber.jpg|thumb|[[Radon]] in air forms a part of the [[background radiation]], which can be observed in a [[cloud chamber]]]] The majority of the dose is caused by the decay of the [[polonium]] (<sup>218</sup>Po) and [[lead]] (<sup>214</sup>Pb) daughters of <sup>222</sup>Rn. By controlling exposure to the daughters the radioactive dose to the [[skin]] and [[lung]]s can be reduced by at least 90%. This can be done by wearing a dust mask, and wearing a suit to cover the entire body. Note that exposure to [[smoke]] at the same time as [[radon]] and radon daughters will increase the harmful effect of the radon. In [[uranium mining|uranium miner]]s radon has been found to be more [[carcinogenic]] in [[Tobacco smoking|smokers]] than in non-smokers.<ref name=profile /> [[Image:Decay chain(4n+2, Uranium series).svg|thumb|alt=Uranium series|The radium or uranium series.]]
=== Occurrence===
Radon concentration in the open air varies between 1 and 100 Bq per cubic metre.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Daily variation of the radon concentration indoors and outdoors and the influence of meteorological parameters.|last = Porstendörfer|first =J.|date = September 1994|journal = Health physics|doi = 10.1097/00004032-199409000-00011|pmid = 8056597|volume=67|issue=3|pages=283–287|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Radon can be found in some [[spring (water)|spring water]]s and [[hot spring]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Evaluation of the exposure levels to radioactivity in the hot-spring environment of the Island of Ischia during a year|last = Bartoli|first = G.|date = 1989|journal = Annali di igiene : medicina preventiva e di comunità|doi = |pmid = 2484503|volume=1|issue=6|pages=1781–1823|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The towns of [[Misasa, Tottori|Misasa]], [[Japan]], and [[Bad Kreuznach]], [[Germany]] boast radium-rich springs which emit radon, as does [[Radium Springs, New Mexico]].
Radon exhausts naturally from the ground, particularly in certain regions, especially but not only regions with [[granite|granitic]] soils. Not all granitic regions are prone to high emissions of radon, for instance while the rock which [[Aberdeen]] is on is very radium rich the rock lacks the cracks required for the radon to migrate. In other nearby areas of Scotland (to the north of Aberdeen) and in [[Cornwall]]/[[Devon]] the radon is very much able to leave the rock.
Radon is a decay product of [[radium]] which in turn is a decay product of uranium. It is possible to acquire maps of average radon levels in houses to assist in the planning of radon mitigation measures for homes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eetd.lbl.gov/IEP/high-radon/USgm.htm |title=Predicted median annual-average living-area concentration, by county |publisher=Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory |accessdate=2008-02-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231195400/http://eetd.lbl.gov/IEP/high-radon/USgm.htm |archivedate=2007-12-31}}</ref>
Note that while high uranium in the [[soil]]/[[Rock (geology)|rock]] under a house does not always lead to a high radon level in air, a positive correlation between the uranium content of the soil and the radon level in air can be seen.
===In air ===
Radon is related to [[indoor air quality]] as it blights many homes. (See "Radon in Houses" below.)
The radon (<sup>222</sup>Rn) released into the air decays to [[lead|<sup>210</sup>Pb]] and other radioisotopes and the levels of <sup>210</sup>Pb can be measured. It is important to note that the rate of deposition of this radioisotope is very dependent on the season. Here is a graph of the deposition rate observed in [[Japan]].<ref>{{Cite journal |url= http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0265931X05002432 |title= Seasonal and spatial variation of atmospheric 210Pb and 7Be deposition: features of the Japan Sea side of Japan |last= Yamamoto |first= Masayoshi |date= September 21, 2005 |journal= Journal of Environmental Radioactivity |doi= 10.1016/j.jenvrad.2005.08.001 |pmid= 16181712 |access-date= January 31, 2015 |issue=1 |pages=110–131 |volume=86 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> [[Image:Lead210inairatjapan.png|upright=2|thumb|Lead-210 deposition rate as a function of time as observed in Japan]]
===In groundwater===
Well water can be very rich in radon; the use of this water inside a house is an additional route allowing radon to enter the house. The radon can enter the air and then be a source of exposure to the humans, or the water can be consumed by humans which is a different exposure route.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://water.epa.gov/lawsregs/rulesregs/sdwa/radon/basicinformation.cfm |title= Basic Information about Radon in Drinking Water |date= June 30, 2014 |accessdate= January 31, 2015 |publisher= United States Environmental Protection Agency |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214054459/http://water.epa.gov/lawsregs/rulesregs/sdwa/radon/basicinformation.cfm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-02-14}}</ref>
===Radon in rainwater=== Rainwater can be intensely radioactive due to high levels of radon and its decay progenies <sup>214</sup>Bi and <sup>214</sup>Pb; the concentrations of these [[radioisotope]]s can be high enough to seriously disrupt radiation monitoring at nuclear power plants.<ref name=Yamazawa>{{Cite conference | doi = 10.1063/1.2991194 | conference = The Natural Radiation Environment | volume = 1034 | pages = 149–152 | last = Yamazawa | first = H. |author2=M. Matsuda |author3=J. Moriizumi |author4=T. Iida | title = Wet Deposition of Radon Decay Products and its Relation with Long-Range Transported Radon | date = 2008 | bibcode = 2008AIPC.1034..149Y }}</ref> The highest levels of radon in rainwater occurs during thunderstorms, and it is hypothesized that radon is concentrated in thunderstorms on account of the atom's positive electrical charge.<ref name=Greenfield-1>{{Cite conference | conference = Bulletin of the American Physical Society | last = Greenfield | first = M.B. |author2=A. Iwata |author3=N. Ito |author4=M. Ishigaki |author5=K. Kubo | title = Intense γ radiation from radon progeny accreted in/on rain during and following thunderstorms | location = Nashville, Tennessee | date = 2006 }}</ref> Estimates of the age of rain drops have been obtained from measuring the isotopic abundance of radon's short-lived decay progeny in rainwater.<ref name=Greenfield-2>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1063/1.2990773 |issn = 0021-8979 |volume = 104 |issue = 7 |id = 074912 |last = Greenfield |first = M. B. |author2 = N. Ito |author3 = A. Iwata |author4 = K. Kubo |author5 = M. Ishigaki |author6 = K. Komura |title = Determination of rain age via γ rays from accreted radon progeny |journal = Journal of Applied Physics |accessdate = 2011-08-23 |year = 2008 |url = http://link.aip.org/link/JAPIAU/v104/i7/p074912/s1&Agg=doi |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130223080358/http://link.aip.org/link/JAPIAU/v104/i7/p074912/s1&Agg=doi |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2013-02-23 |bibcode = 2008JAP...104g4912G }}</ref>
===In the oil and gas industries ===
The water, oil and gas from a well often contains [[radon]]. The radon decays to form solid radioisotopes which form coatings on the inside of pipework. In an oil processing plant the area of the plant where [[propane]] is processed is often one of the more contaminated areas of the plant as radon has a similar boiling point to propane.<ref>{{cite web |title=Survey & Identification of NORM Contaminated Equipment |url=http://www.enprotec-inc.com/Presentations/NORM.pdf |publisher=Enprotec / Hibbs & Todd |date=October 2004}}</ref>
===In mines ===
Because uranium minerals emit [[radon]] gas, and their harmful and highly radioactive [[decay product|daughter products]], uranium mining is considerably more dangerous than other (already dangerous) [[Underground mining (hard rock)|hard rock mining]], requiring adequate ventilation systems if the mines are not [[open-pit mining|open pit]]. During the 1950s, a significant number of American uranium miners were [[Navajo Nation|Navajo]] Indians, as many uranium deposits were discovered on Navajo [[Indian reservation|reservations]]. A statistically significant subset of these miners later developed [[small-cell lung cancer]], a type of cancer usually not associated with smoking, after exposure to uranium ore and [[radon]]-222, a natural decay product of uranium.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Gottlieb |first=Leon S. |last2=Husen |first2=Luverne A. |title=Lung Cancer Among Navajo Uranium Miners |date=April 1982 |journal=Chest |volume=81 |issue=4 |pages=449–452 |doi=10.1378/chest.81.4.449}}</ref> The radon, which is produced by the uranium, and not the uranium itself has been shown to be the cancer causing agent.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Harley |first=Naomi |date=1999 |last2=Foulkes |first2=Ernest |last3=Hilborne |first3=Lee H. |last4=Hudson |first4=Arlene |last5=Anthony |first5=C. Ross |title=A Review of the Scientific Literature As It Pertains to Gulf War Illnesses: Volume 7: Depleted Uranium |url=https://www.rand.org/pubs/monograph_reports/MR1018z7.html |publisher=RAND Corp. |language=en |page=28}}</ref> Some survivors and their descendants received compensation under the [[Radiation Exposure Compensation Act]] in 1990.
Currently the level of radon in the air of mines is normally controlled by [[law]]. In a working mine, the radon level can be controlled by [[Ventilation (architecture)|ventilation]], sealing off old workings and controlling the water in the mine. The level in a mine can go up when a mine is abandoned, it can reach a level which is able to cause the [[skin]] to become [[red]] (a mild [[radiation burn]]). The radon levels in some of the mines can reach 400 to 700 kBq m<sup>−3</sup>.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Assessment of health risks to skin and lung of elevated radon levels in abandoned mines.|last = Denman|first = A.R.|date = December 2003|journal = Health Physics|doi = 10.1097/00004032-200312000-00018|pmid = 14626324|last2 = Eatough|first2 = J.P.|first3 = G.|first4 = P.S.|last3 = Gillmore|last4 = Phillips|issue = 6|pages = 733–739|volume=85}}</ref>
A common unit of exposure of lung tissue to [[alpha emitter]]s is the [[Working level|working level month]] ('''WLM'''), this is where the human [[lung]]s have been exposed for 170 hours (a typical month worth of work for a miner) to air which has 3.7 kBq of <sup>222</sup>Rn (in equilibrium with its decay products). This is air which has the alpha dose rate of 1 [[working level]] ('''WL'''). It is estimated that the average person (''[[general public]]'') is subject to 0.2 WLM per year, which works out at about 15 to 20 WLM in a lifetime. According to the NRC 1 WLM is a 5 to 10 mSv lung dose (0.5 to 1.0 [[Röntgen equivalent man|rem]]), while the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) consider that 1 WLM is equal to a lung dose of 5.5 mSv, the [[International Commission on Radiological Protection]] (ICRP) consider 1 WLM to be a 5 mSv lung dose for professional workers (and 4 mSv lung dose for the general public). Lastly the [[United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation]] (UNSCEAR) consider that the exposure of the lungs to 1 Bq of <sup>222</sup>Rn (in equilibrium with its decay products) for one year will cause a dose of 61 μSv.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Radioactivity, Ionizing Radiation, and Nuclear Energy|last = Hala|first = Jiri|publisher = Konvoj|year = 2003|isbn = 9788073020538|location = |pages = |last2 = Navratil|first2 = James}}</ref>
In humans a relationship between [[lung cancer]] and radon has been shown to exist (beyond all reasonable doubt) for exposures of 100 WLM and above. By using the data from several studies it has been possible to show that an increased risk can be caused by a dose as low as 15 to 20 WLM. Sadly these studies have been difficult as the random errors in the data are very large. It is likely that the miners are also subject to other effects which can harm their lungs while at work (for example dust and [[Diesel exhaust|diesel]] fumes).
===In houses ===
The fact that radon is present in indoor air has been known at least since 1950s and research on its effects on human health started on early 1970s.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Monographs/vol43/|title = Man-made Mineral Fibres and Radon|date = 1988|journal = IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of Carcinogenic Risks to Humans|doi = |pmid = |access-date = January 31, 2015|issue = 43}}</ref> The danger of radon exposure in [[dwellings]] received more widespread public awareness after 1984, as a result of a case of [[Health effects of radon#Stanley Watras|Stanley Watras]], an employee at the [[Limerick nuclear power plant]] in [[Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Indoor radon and lung cancer. Estimating the risks.|last = Samet|first = J. M.|date = January 1992|journal = Western Journal of Medicine|doi = |pmid = 1734594|pmc=1003141|volume=156|issue=1|pages=25–29}}</ref> Mr. Watras set off the [[radiation]] alarms (see [[Geiger counter]]) on his way ''into'' work for two weeks straight while authorities searched for the source of the [[contamination]]. They were shocked to find that the source was astonishingly high levels of radon in his [[basement]] and it was not related to the nuclear plant. The risks associated with living in his house were estimated to be equivalent to [[Tobacco smoking|smoking]] 135 packs of [[cigarette]]s every day.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://oldweb.northampton.ac.uk/aps/env/wastes/radon_hotline/radonstory.htm|title = The Radon Story|date = 2001|accessdate = January 1, 2015|website = |publisher = The Radon Council|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://archive.is/20150201024505/http://oldweb.northampton.ac.uk/aps/env/wastes/radon_hotline/radonstory.htm|archivedate = February 1, 2015|df = }}</ref>
Depending on how houses are built and ventilated, radon may accumulate in basements and dwellings. The [[European Union]] recommends that [[Radon mitigation|mitigation]] should be taken starting from concentrations of 400 [[Becquerel|Bq]]/m<sup>3</sup> for old houses, and 200 Bq/m<sup>3</sup> for new ones.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.polisproject.org/PDFs/Radon%20report%20DSF.doc|title = Radon The Unfamiliar Killer|last = Boyd|first = David R.|journal = |doi = |pmid = |access-date = February 1, 2015|publisher = David Suzuki Foundation|year = 2006|series = Healthy Environment, Healthy Canadians Series, Report No.1|location = Vancouver}}</ref>
The [[National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements]] (NCRP) recommends action for any house with a concentration higher than 8 [[Curie|pCi]]/L (300 Bq/m³).
The [[United States]] [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] recommends action for any house with a concentration higher than 148 Bq/m<sup>3</sup> (given as 4 [[Curie|pCi]]/L). Nearly one in 15 homes in the U.S. has a high level of indoor radon according to their statistics. The U.S. Surgeon General and EPA recommend all homes be tested for radon. Since 1985, millions of homes have been tested for radon in the U.S.<ref name=":0" />
By adding a crawl space under the ground floor, which is subject to forced ventilation the radon level in the house can be lowered.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Design and Testing of Sub-Slab Depressurization for Radon Mitigation in North Florida Houses: Part I - Performance and Durability|last = Roessler|first = C. E.|publisher = United States Environmental Protection Agency|year = 1996|isbn = |location = Research Triangle Park, NC 27711|pages = |url = http://infohouse.p2ric.org/ref/07/06295.pdf|display-authors=etal}}</ref>

{{Orphan|date=January 2011}} A '''Refractory lined expansion joint''' is an assembly used in a pipe line to allow it to expand and contract<ref>[http://www.usbellows.com/expansion-joint-catalog/expansion_joint-glossary.htm#EXPANSION%20JOINTS Expansion Joints] Glossary of Terms, (retrieved 30 October 2010)</ref> as climate conditions move from hot to cold and helps to ensure that the system remains functional. The refractory-lining can be vibra cast insulation with anchors, abrasion resistant refractory in hex mesh, gunned insulating refractory, or poured insulating refractory. Refractory lined expansion joints can be hinged, in-line pressure balanced, gimbal, tied-universal depending on the temperature, pressure, movement and flow media conditions.<ref>[http://www.usbellows.com/products/refractory-lined-expansion-joint.htm U.S. Bellows] Refractory Lined Expansion Joints (retrieved February 2012)</ref> [[image:Refractory-lined-joint.jpg|thumb|alt=Refractory Lined Expansion Joint|Expansion Joint with Refractory Lining - U.S. Bellows, Inc.]]
Refractory lined [[Expansion joint]]s are used in extremely high temperature and high pressure applications and are designed to withstand extreme environments. The [[Refractory]] lining within the metallic [[Expansion joint]] bellows functions to reduce the
pipe wall temperature by 300˚F to 450˚F, depending upon the thickness of the refractory lining.<ref>[http://www.usbellows.com/products/refractory_joint.htm Refractory Lined Expansion Joints] U.S. Bellows, Inc., (retrieved 30 October 2010)</ref> The lining also helps to withstand the abrasive material from the catalyst in FCCU applications.<ref>[http://www.touchoilandgas.com/maintenance-tips-critical-expansion-a8079-1.html Key Maintenance Tips for Critical Expansion Joint Applications] Touch Oil and Gas, (retrieved 30 October 2010)</ref>
== Applications == * [[Fluid catalytic cracking]] Units (FCCU) * Furnaces * Hot gas turbines * Styrene plants * Fluidized bed boilers * Kilns * Power recovery trains * Thermal oxidizers
